q.p: THEREFORE ALL THINGS WHATSOEVER YOU WOULD, THAT MEN SHOULD DO TO YOU, DO YE EVEN SO TO THEM; FOR THIS IS THE LAW AND THE PROPHETS.

div.p:
THIS precept of our divine Lord hath always been admired as mo≈øt excellent; and doubtle≈øs with the greate≈øt rea≈øon. Yet it needs ≈øome explanation. It is not ≈øurely to be under≈øtood in the mo≈øt unlimited ≈øen≈øe, implying that becau≈øe a prince expects and wi≈øhes for obedience from his ≈øubjects, he is obliged to obey them: that becau≈øe parents wi≈øh their children to ≈øubmit to their government, therefore they are to ≈øubmit to the government of their children: or that becau≈øe ≈øome men wi≈øh that others would concur and a≈ø≈øi≈øt them to the gratification of their unlawful de≈øires, therefore they al≈øo are to gratify the unlawful de≈øires of others. But whatever we are con≈øcious, that we ≈øhould, in an exchange of circum≈øtances, wi≈øh, and are per≈øuaded that we might rea≈øonably wi≈øh, that others would do to us; that we are bound to do to them. This is the general rule given us in the
text; and a very exten≈øive rule it is, reaching to the whole of our conduct: and is particularly u≈øeful to direct our conduct toward inferiours, and tho≈øe whom we have in our power. I have therefore thought it a proper foundation for the di≈øcour≈øe which by the Society for the Promotion of Freedom, and for the Relief of Per≈øons unlawfully holden in Bondage, I have the honour to be appointed to deliver, on the pre≈øent occa≈øion.
This divine maxim is mo≈øt properly applicable to the ≈ølave-trade, and to the ≈ølavery of the Africans. Let us then make the application.

Should we be willing, that the Africans or any other nation ≈øhould purcha≈øe us, our wives and children, tran≈øport us into Africa and there ≈øell us into perpetual and ab≈øolute ≈ølavery? Should we be willing, that they by large bribes and offers of a gainful traffic ≈øhould entice our neighbours to kidnap and ≈øell us to them, and that they ≈øhould hold in perpetual and cruel bondage, not only our≈øelves, but our po≈øterity through all generations? Yet why is it not as right for them to treat us in this manner, as it is for us to treat them in the ≈øame manner? Their colour indeed is different from our's. But does this give us a right to en≈ølave them? The nations from Germany to Guinea have complexions of every ≈øhade from the faire≈øt white, to a jetty black: and if a black complexion ≈øubject a nation or an individual to ≈ølavery; where ≈øhall ≈ølavery begin? or where ≈øhall it end?

I propo≈øe to mention a few rea≈øons again≈øt the right of the ≈ølave-trade‚Äîand then to con≈øider the principal arguments, which I have ever heard urged in favour of it.‚ÄîWhat will be ≈øaid again≈øt the ≈ølave-trade will generally be equally applicable to ≈ølavery it≈øelf; and if conclu≈øive again≈øt the former, will be equally conclu≈øive again≈øt the latter.

As to the ≈ølave-trade, I conceive it to be unju≈øt in it≈øelf‚Äîabominable on account of the cruel manner in which it is conducted‚Äîand totally wrong on account of the impolicy of it, or its de≈øtructive tendency to the moral and political intere≈øts of any country.

I. It is unju≈øt in it≈øelf.‚ÄîIt is unju≈øt in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe, and for the ≈øame rea≈øon, as it is, to ≈øteal, to rob, or to murder. It is a principle, the truth of which hath in this country been generally, if not univer≈øally acknowledged, ever ≈øince the commencement of the late war, that all men are born equally free. If this be true, the Africans are by nature equally entitled to freedom as we are; and therefore we have no more right to en≈ølave, or to afford aid to en≈ølave them, than they have to do the ≈øame to us. They have the ≈øame right to their freedom, which they have to their property or to their lives. Therefore to en≈ølave them is as really and in the ≈øame ≈øen≈øe wrong, as to ≈øteal from them, to rob or to murder them.

There are indeed ca≈øes in which men may ju≈øtly be deprived of their liberty and reduced to ≈ølavery; as there are ca≈øes in which they may be ju≈øtly deprived of their lives. But they can ju≈øtly be deprived of neither, unle≈øs they have by their own voluntary conduct forfeited it. Therefore ≈øtill the right to liberty ≈øtands on the ≈øame ba≈øis with the right to life. And that the Africans have done ≈øomething whereby they have forfeited their liberty mu≈øt appear, before we can ju≈øtly deprive them of it; as it mu≈øt appear, that they have done ≈øomething whereby they have forfeited their lives, before we may ju≈øtly deprive them of the≈øe.
II. The ≈ølave-trade is wicked and abominable on account of the cruel manner in which it is carried on.

Be≈øide the ≈øtealing or kidnapping of men, women and children, in the fir≈øt in≈øtance, and the in≈øtigation of others to this abominable practice; the inhuman manner in which they are tran≈øported to America, and in which they are treated on their pa≈ø≈øage and in their ≈øub≈øequent ≈ølavery, is ≈øuch as ought forever to deter every man from acting any part in this bu≈øine≈øs, who has any regard to ju≈øtice or humanity. They are crowded ≈øo clo≈øely into the holds and between the decks of ve≈ø≈øels, that they have ≈øcarcely room to lie down, and ≈øometimes not room to ≈øit up in an erect po≈øture; the men at the ≈øame time fa≈øtened together with irons by two and two; and all this in the mo≈øt ≈øultry climate. The con≈øequence of the whole is, that the mo≈øt dangerous and fatal di≈øea≈øes are ≈øoon bred among them, whereby va≈øt numbers of tho≈øe exported from Africa peri≈øh in the voyage: others in dread of that ≈ølavery which is before them, and in di≈øtre≈øs and de≈øpair from the lo≈øs of their parents, their children, their hu≈øbands, their wives, all their dear connections, and their dear native country it≈øelf, ≈øtarve them≈øelves to death or plunge them≈øelves into the ocean. Tho≈øe who attempt in the former of tho≈øe ways to e≈øcape from their per≈øecutors, are tortured by live coals applied to their mouths. Tho≈øe who attempt an e≈øcape in the latter and fail, are equally tortured by the mo≈øt cruel beating, or otherwi≈øe as their per≈øecutors plea≈øe. If any of them make an attempt, as they ≈øometimes do, to recover their liberty, ≈øome, and as the circum≈øtances may be, many, are put to immediate death. Others beaten, brui≈øed, cut and mangled in a mo≈øt inhuman and ≈øhocking manner, are in this ≈øituation exhibited to the re≈øt, to terrify them from the like attempt in future: and ≈øome are delivered up to every ≈øpecies of torment, whether by the application of the whip,
or of any other in≈øtrument, even of fire it≈øelf, as the ingenuity of the ≈øhip-ma≈øter and of his crew is able to ≈øugge≈øt or their ≈øituation will admit; and the≈øe torments are purpo≈øely continued for ≈øeveral days, before death is permitted to afford relief to the≈øe objects of vengeance.

By the≈øe means, according to the common computation, twenty-five thou≈øand, which is a fourth part of tho≈øe who are exported from Africa, and by the conce≈ø≈øion of all, twenty thou≈øand, annually peri≈øh, before they arrive at the places of their de≈øtination in America.

But this is by no means the end of the ≈øufferings of this unhappy people. Bred up in a country ≈øpontaneou≈øly yielding the nece≈ø≈øaries and conveniences of ≈øavage life, they have never been accu≈øtomed to labour: of cour≈øe they are but ill prepared to go through the fatigue and drudgery to which they are doomed in their ≈øtate of ≈ølavery. Therefore partly by this cau≈øe, partly by the ≈øcantine≈øs and badne≈øs of their food, and partly from dejection of ≈øpirits, mortification and de≈øpair, another twenty-five thou≈øand die in the ≈øea≈øoning, as it is called, i. e. within two years of their arrival in America. This I ≈øay is the common computation. Or if we will in this particular be as favourable to the trade as in the e≈øtimate of the number which peri≈øhes on the pa≈ø≈øage, we may reckon the number which dies in the ≈øea≈øoning to be twenty thou≈øand. So that of the hundred thou≈øand annually exported from Africa to America, fifty thou≈øand, as it is commonly computed, or on the mo≈øt favourable e≈øtimate, forty thou≈øand, die before they are ≈øea≈øoned to the country.

Nor is this all. The cruel ≈øufferings of the≈øe pitiable beings are not yet at an end. Thenceforward
they have to drag out a mi≈øerable life in ab≈øolute ≈ølavery, entirely at the di≈øpo≈øal of their ma≈øters, by whom not only every venial fault, every mere inadvertence or mi≈øtake, but even real virtues, are liable to be con≈øtrued into the mo≈øt atrocious crimes, and puni≈øhed as ≈øuch, according to their caprice or rage, while they are intoxicated ≈øometimes with liquor, ≈øometimes with pa≈ø≈øion.

By the≈øe ma≈øters they are ≈øupplied with barely enough to keep them from ≈øtarving, as the whole expence laid out on a ≈ølave for food, clothing and medicine is commonly computed on an average at thirty ≈øhillings ≈øterling annually. At the ≈øame time they are kept at hard labour from five o'clock in the morning, till nine at night, excepting time to eat twice during the day. And they are con≈øtantly under the watchful eye of over≈øeers and Negro-drivers more tyrannical and cruel than even their ma≈øters them≈øelves. From the≈øe drivers for every imagined, as well as real neglect or want of exertion, they receive the la≈øh, the ≈ømack of which is all day long in the ears of tho≈øe who are on the plantation or in the vicinity; and it is u≈øed with ≈øuch dexterity and ≈øeverity, as not only to lacerate the ≈økin, but to tear out ≈ømall portions of the fle≈øh at almo≈øt every ≈øtroke.

This is the general treatment of the ≈ølaves. But many individuals ≈øuffer ≈øtill more ≈øeverely. Many, many are knocked down; ≈øome have their eyes beaten out; ≈øome have an arm or a leg broken, or chopt off; and many for a very ≈ømall or for no crime at all, have been beaten to death merely to gratify the fury of an enraged ma≈øter or over≈øeer.

Nor ought we on this occa≈øion to overlook the wars among the nations of Africa excited by the trade, or the de≈øtruction attendant on tho≈øe wars. Not to mention the de≈øtruction of property, the
burning of towns and villages, &c. it hath been determined by rea≈øonable computation, that there are annually exported from Africa to the various parts of America, one hundred thou≈øand ≈ølaves, as was before ob≈øerved; that of the≈øe ≈øix thou≈øand are captives of war; that in the wars in which the≈øe are taken, ten per≈øons of the victors and vanqui≈øhed are killed, to one taken; that therefore the taking of the ≈øix thou≈øand captives is attended with the ≈ølaughter of ≈øixty thou≈øand of their countrymen. Now does not ju≈øtice? does not humanity ≈øhrink from the idea, that in order to procure one ≈ølave to gratify our avarice, we ≈øhould put to death ten human beings? Or that in order to increa≈øe our property, and that only in ≈øome ≈ømall degree, we ≈øhould carry on a trade, or even connive at it, to ≈øupport which ≈øixty thou≈øand of our own ≈øpecies are ≈ølain in war?

The≈øe ≈øixty thou≈øand, added to the forty thou≈øand who peri≈øh on the pa≈ø≈øage and in the ≈øea≈øoning, give us an hundred thou≈øand who are annually de≈øtroyed by the trade; and the whole advantage gained by this amazing de≈øtruction of human lives is ≈øixty thou≈øand ≈ølaves. For you will recollect, that the whole number exported from Africa is an hundred thou≈øand; that of the≈øe forty thou≈øand die on the pa≈ø≈øage and in the ≈øea≈øoning, and ≈øixty thou≈øand are de≈øtroyed in the wars. Therefore while one hundred and ≈øixty thou≈øand are killed in the wars and are exported from Africa, but ≈øixty thou≈øand are added to the ≈øtock of ≈ølaves.

Now when we con≈øider all this; when we con≈øider the mi≈øeries which this unhappy people ≈øuffer in their wars, in their captivity, in their voyage to America, and during a wretched life of cruel ≈ølavery: and e≈øpecially when we con≈øider the annual de≈øtruction of an hundred thou≈øand lives in the manner before mentioned; who can he≈øitate to declare
this trade and the con≈øequent ≈ølavery to be contrary to every principle of ju≈øtice and humanity, of the law of nature and of the law of God?
III. This trade and this ≈ølavery are utterly wrong on the ground of impolicy. In a variety of re≈øpects they are exceedingly hurtful to the ≈øtate which tolerates them.

1. They are hurtful, as they deprave the morals of the people.‚ÄîThe ince≈ø≈øant and inhuman cruelties practi≈øed in the trade and in the ≈øub≈øequent ≈ølavery nece≈ø≈øarily tend to harden the human heart again≈øt the tender feelings of humanity in the ma≈øters of ve≈ø≈øels, in the ≈øailors, in the factors, in the proprietors of the ≈ølaves, in their children, in the over≈øeers, in the ≈ølaves them≈øelves, and in all who habitually ≈øee tho≈øe cruelties. Now the eradication or even the diminution of compa≈ø≈øion, tenderne≈øs and humanity, is certainly a great depravation of heart, and mu≈øt be followed with corre≈øpondent depravity of manners. And mea≈øures which lead to ≈øuch depravity of heart and manners, cannot but be extremely hurtful to the ≈øtate, and con≈øequently are extremely impolitic.

2. The trade is impolitic as it is ≈øo de≈øtructive of the lives of ≈øeamen. The ingenious Mr. Clark≈øon hath in a very ≈øatisfactory manner made it appear, that in the ≈ølave-trade alone Great-Britain lo≈øes annually about nineteen hundred ≈øeamen; and that this lo≈øs is more than double to the lo≈øs annually ≈øu≈øtained by Great-Britain in all her other trade taken together. And doubtle≈øs we lo≈øe as many as Great-Britain in proportion to the number of ≈øeamen whom we employ in this trade.‚ÄîNow can it be politic to carry on a trade which is ≈øo de≈øtructive of that u≈øeful part of our citizens, our ≈øeamen?

3. African ≈ølavery is exceedingly impolitic, as it di≈øcourages indu≈øtry. Nothing is more e≈ø≈øential to the political pro≈øperity of any ≈øtate, than indu≈øtry in
the citizens. But in proportion as ≈ølaves are multiplied, every kind of labour becomes ignominious: and in fact in tho≈øe of the United States, in which ≈ølaves are the mo≈øt numerous, gentlemen and ladies of any fa≈øhion di≈ødain to employ them≈øelves in bu≈øine≈øs, which in other ≈øtates is con≈øi≈øtent with the dignity of the fir≈øt families and fir≈øt offices. In a country filled with Negro ≈ølaves, labour belongs to them only, and a white man is de≈øpi≈øed in proportion as he applies to it.‚ÄîNow how de≈øtructive to indu≈øtry in all of the lowe≈øt and middle cla≈øs of citizens, ≈øuch a ≈øituation and the prevalence of ≈øuch ideas will be, you can ea≈øily conceive. The con≈øequence is, that ≈øome will nearly ≈øtarve, others will betake them≈øelves to the mo≈øt di≈øhone≈øt practices, to obtain the means of living.

As ≈ølavery produces indolence in the white people, ≈øo it produces all tho≈øe vices which are naturally connected with it; ≈øuch as intemperance, lewdne≈øs and prodigality. The≈øe vices enfeeble both the body and the mind, and unfit men for any vigorous exertions and employments either external or mental. And tho≈øe who are unfit for ≈øuch exertions, are already a very degenerate race; degenerate, not only in a moral, but a natural ≈øen≈øe. They are contemptible too, and will ≈øoon be de≈øpi≈øed even by their Negroes them≈øelves.

Slavery tends to lewdne≈øs not only as it produces indolence, but as it affords abundant opportunity for that wickedne≈øs without either the danger and difficulty of an attack on the virtue of a woman of cha≈øtity, or the danger of a connection with one of ill fame. mulattoes in countries where ≈ølaves are very numerous.

Slavery has a mo≈øt direct tendency to haughtine≈øs al≈øo, and a domineering ≈øpirit and conduct in the proprietors of the ≈ølaves, in their children, and in all who have the control of them. A man who has been bred up in domineering over Negroes, can ≈øcarcely avoid contracting ≈øuch a habit of haughtine≈øs and domination, as will expre≈øs it≈øelf in his general treatment of mankind, whether in his private capacity, or in any office civil or military with which he may be ve≈øted. 4. In the ≈øame proportion as indu≈øtry and labour are di≈øcouraged, is population di≈øcouraged and prevented. This is another re≈øpect in which ≈ølavery is exceedingly impolitic. That population is prevented in proportion as indu≈øtry is di≈øcouraged, is, I conceive, ≈øo plain that nothing needs to be ≈øaid to illu≈øtrate it. But the great body of any people have no other way of ≈øupporting them≈øelves or a family, than by their own labour. Of cour≈øe as labour is di≈øcouraged, matrimony is di≈øcouraged and population is prevented.‚ÄîBut the impolicy of whatever produces the≈øe effects will be acknowledged by all. The wealth, ≈øtrength and glory of a ≈øtate depend on the number of its virtuous citizens: and a ≈øtate without citizens is at lea≈øt as great an ab≈øurdity, as a king without ≈øubjects.

5. The impolicy of ≈ølavery ≈øtill further appears from this, that it weakens the ≈øtate, and in proportion to the degree in which it exi≈øts, expo≈øes it to become an ea≈øy conque≈øt.‚ÄîThe increa≈øe of free citizens is an increa≈øe of the ≈øtrength of the ≈øtate. But not ≈øo with regard to the increa≈øe of ≈ølaves. They not only add nothing to the ≈øtrength of the ≈øtate, but actually dimini≈øh it in proportion to their number. Every ≈ølave is naturally an enemy to the ≈øtate in which he is holden in ≈ølavery, and wants nothing but an opportunity to a≈ø≈øi≈øt in its overthrow. The≈øe ob≈øervations concerning the prevention of population and weakening the ≈øtate, are ≈øupported by facts which have fallen within our own ob≈øervation.
